pull.title: wallet: migration, avoid creating spendable wallet from a watch-only legacy wallet
pull.body:
Currently, the migration process creates a brand-new descriptor wallet with no
connection to the user's legacy wallet when the legacy wallet lacks key material
and contains only watch-only scripts. This behavior is not aligned with user
expectations. If the legacy wallet contains only watch-only scripts, the migration
process should only generate a watch-only wallet instead.

TODO List:
* Explain that `migratewallet` renames the watch-only after migration, and
also that the wallet will not have keys enabled.

I've tested this branch ([6d9bf36](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/commit/6d9bf36b2c061088abb0d839fee90683ff1525e1)) and I still got "**bad_function_call**", as mentioned in my previous [testing](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/31423#pullrequestreview-2694630661), when I try to migrate a blank legacy wallet with an imported address. I've isolated the case and it's only happening on a blank wallet with private keys enabled (disabled private keys on blank wallet with imported address works fine).

Steps to reproduce the issue (first create a legacy wallet using v28):
- start the node with `./releases/v28.0/bin/bitcoind -regtest -datadir=/tmp/btc -deprecatedrpc=create_bdb`
- on a diff terminal `./releases/v28.0/bin/bitcoin-cli -regtest -datadir=/tmp/btc createwallet "legacy_bad_call" false true "" false false`
- same terminal as above `./releases/v28.0/bin/bitcoin-cli -regtest -datadir=/tmp/btc -rpcwallet=legacy_bad_call importaddress bcrt1q5suud4au3ydeatsvu3afj2dky2cz66w2w5zxhm` (an address from another legacy wallet)
- stop the v28 node
- start a node with this branch `./build/bin/bitcoind -regtest -datadir=/tmp/btc`
- on a diff terminal `./build/bin/bitcoin-cli -regtest -datadir=/tmp/btc migratewallet legacy_bad_call`
```
error code: -1
error message:
bad_function_call
```


The steps above work fine on `master`:
```
./build/bin/bitcoin-cli -regtest -datadir=/tmp/btc migratewallet legacy_bad_call
{
  "wallet_name": "legacy_bad_call",
  "watchonly_name": "legacy_bad_call_watchonly",
  "backup_path": "/tmp/btc/regtest/wallets/legacy_bad_call/legacy_bad_call_1748481476.legacy.bak"
}

```

In 788bb48f6712c39995831020dc36297f88c42f71 "wallet: introduce method to return all db created files"

These are created only by BDB.

SQLite makes only `wallet.dat` and `wallet.dat-journal`.
Fixed. Thanks.

Any reasons why you wouldn't use `std::filesystem::path::string` instead (same for other instances):
```suggestion
        LogPrintf("Using wallet %s\n", m_dir_path.string());
```

nit (to add a bit of clarity - I also think this `CWallet::ApplyMigrationData` should be refactored, at least extracting some behaviour into functions to begin with if possible):
```suggestion
    bool is_local_wallet_empty = data.desc_spkms.empty() && !data.master_key.key.IsValid();
```

Although I'm not convinced that I understand clearly what the problems are, a description of why `std::filesystem::path::string` is not used is in #22937, which introduced `fs::PathToString()` and `fs::StringToPath()` to avoid use of `std::filesystem::path::string` where previously `boost::filesystem::path::string` was used:

Commit message of https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/22937/commits/6544ea5035268025207d2402db2f7d90fde947a6: 
> #### Block unsafe fs::path std::string conversion calls
> There is no change in behavior. This just helps prepare for the
transition from boost::filesystem to std::filesystem by avoiding calls
to methods which will be unsafe after the transaction to std::filesystem
to due lack of a boost::filesystem::path::imbue equivalent and inability
to set a predictable locale.

nit, maybe while you are touching this anyways:

```suggestion
    const fs::path m_file_path;
```

but, this is less clear of a win since `SQLiteDatabase::Filename()` will have to convert it back.

(https://github.com/davidgumberg/bitcoin/commit/9f85c1f45c6f808f37ab3715578a8f213a74fe6b)
It seems there are inefficiencies in the string constructor used within plus it brings issues on Windows.

re: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/31423#discussion_r2034107379

Yes the only reason `PathToString` exists is because on windows the `path::string()` method depends on the current locale and won't work reliably. The `path::utf8string()` method could be used instead but this doesn't work relliably on unix, so a wrapper is needed. The code comments try to explain this but maybe could be improved:

https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/bb92bb36f211b88e4c1aa031a4364795cbd24767/src/util/fs.h#L153-L162
Yes. I don't see any benefit of doing it now.

This has been resolved recently in #32149:

https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/a4fd565191e3184a174757f7a8fbda6afc98e50a/src/wallet/wallet.cpp#L4537-L4544
if your implementation works, we could replace the current sqlite `Files()` code for your code (using `sqlite3_filename_database` and `sqlite3_filename_journal` instead of the hardcoded path).
